‘You say Katerina Ivanovna’s mind is unhinged; your own mind is unhinged,’ he said.

He paced the room, eyes glittering. He approached her, hands on her shoulders. 

His eyes pierced her tearful face. 

Suddenly, he dropped to the ground and kissed her foot. 

Sonia recoiled. 

‘What are you doing to me?’ she muttered, pale with anguish.

He stood up. 

‘I bowed down to all the suffering of humanity,’ he said, wild-eyed. 

‘Listen,’ he turned back. ‘I told an insolent man he wasn’t worth your little finger.’ 

‘You said that in her presence?’ Sonia cried, frightened. 

‘It was not because of your sin,’ he said solemnly. ‘But your suffering. You are a great sinner.’ 

‘Why did you say that?’ she whispered. 

‘You’ve betrayed yourself for nothing. Isn’t that fearful?’

**PAGE SUMMARY:** Raskolnikov expresses his anguish over Sonia's suffering and self-betrayal, highlighting the contrast between her dishonor and the dignity of her suffering.
